STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 31, 2023
Mark Kwarciany
Delta/Dickinson/Menominee DHHS
305 Ludington ST,
Escanaba, MI, 49829-4056
Re: License #: CP210201090
Dear Mr. Kwarciany:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
September 26, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, Area Manager, at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Douglas Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable.
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Parents who are a member of
a participating household. • Youth ages 14 and older. •
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
Four foster care files and 13 service plans were reviewed. Two of four files and 13
service plans documented late signatures or lacked signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
Renewal 09/21/2022. CAP Approved 09/27/2023.
R 400.12413 Medical and Dental
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must include all the
following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3 months
before entry into foster care or an initial dental examination must
be completed not more than 90 calendar days after entry into a
foster care out-of-home placement. A child entering foster care
2

under 1 year of age must have an initial dental exam within 3
months of his or her first birthday.
Four foster care files were reviewed. One of four documented a late dental exam.
The child was placed on March 24, 2023, and the dental exam occurred on June 27,
2023.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Technical assistance was offered regarding policy FOM 722-06B, Family Team
Meetings. It was recommended that case reassessment FTM's be scheduled
farther in advance of the case service plan due date thereby preventing the
possibility of the required FTM occurring after the case plan due date.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not offered or requested at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one corrective action plan during this period under review.
The CAP was submitted on September 27, 2022, in response to the violations
established during the renewal inspection completed on September 21, 2022. The
agency CAP was sucessful in preventing repeat violations except for the one
repeat violation established during the current interim inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators assessment was submitted and reviewed. The
assessment was thorough and detailed. The assessment documented agency
efforts to comply with the CAP submitted on September 27, 2022. The
assessment also documented staff vacancies that created increased caseloads
and travel time for existing staff. The assessment further addressed disrupted
placements, the needs of children being too severe to be maintained in a
community setting.
Financial Overview
N/A as DHHS local office.
3

Staff Youth Interviews
Staff reported feeling supported by the agency administration and their
supervisors. Staff further reported that they feel they are part of a supportive team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is a local DHHS office. The agency is spacious and well maintained.
CHRI documentation was stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst initiated one safety alert during her visit to the homes. The safety
alert is as follows.
Safety Alert 1: A safety alert was generated on June 16, 2023, as a foster home did
not have a smoke alarm installed in lower-level bedroom area.
Resolution: The agency purchased smoke alarms for the family, and they were
installed on June 16, 2023. A photo of the installed alarm was provided and
uploaded into the system.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
October 25, 2023
________________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 31, 2023

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
